ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Being able to do integrals in particular is pretty critical for day-to-day work for so many natural science, engineering, and social science fields. Pretty self-explanatory.
I learned a more theoretical approach to calculus.

I gained a good insight into the concepts of single-variable calculus. Although I struggled when it came to answering exam-level questions, I always felt as though I had a good basic understanding of the course material.

I developed knowledge in certain math concepts, but most importantly I gained the ability to learn on my own and teach myself course content. The biggest insight I took away was the necessity to go over whole topics on your own or else you will miss key concepts that will be covered on both psets and exams.
I have a greater understanding of calculus, and I know recognize the difficulty of college level math.
Math and practice problem concepts.
I gained in-depth knowledge of calculus. I learned new skills on how to adapt knowledge and prepare for exams. I also developed skills of preparation and adaption to finding other resources of help.
Learning to get better at lecture style math class. There is a lot more outside review necessary.
Intermediate calculus knowledge.
I learnt integration strategies, parametric equations, polar coordinates, divergence and convergence tests, etc.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The exams are by far the greatest weakness of this course. They are often unexpectedly difficult and demand a conceptual knowledge of the topics on another level from the problem sets -- the problem sets really shouldn't be harder than the exams. That being said, the pre-class "Explores" were very helpful and I have not seen them in other courses at Yale. It's nice to know the details of what will be covered before you even arrive in class.
The Canvas explorations were very helpful, but the in-person teaching was not very engaging, at least in my case.

The strengths of this course are the pre-class explorations/quizzes, the online videos, the organization, the peer tutors, the office hours, and the helpful outside resources. The weakness of this course is that it does not prepare you well for the tests and exams. The exam questions are almost always more difficult than anything we're ever exposed to in the course (online questions, PSETs, and class exercises).

The strength of this course was the quality of a couple of the peer tutors in aiding student learning, often more than professors. The weaknesses of this course were its lack of communication, it's inability to consistently post psets early enough, and its lack of good professors that can at least disclose the necessary topics we'll need to cover on our own to be successful on the exam. Most of this can be improved with better communication, stricter guidelines for professors, and a curve to alleviate the stress of students who are simply trying to learn under such poor guidance.

The lessons often seemed to lack context, and the problems we went over in class did not correspond well to the problem sets or exams. The online explorations were set to match the desired pace of the class, not the actual pace, so they were utterly unhelpful once we got a single lesson behind. I often received no feedback on incorrect problem set answers.
My strengths were the problem sets and being on top of all the work. My weaknesses were midterm preparations.
More individualized.
The staff was extremely well organized, everything was very clear and laid out.
A centralised note system would help if class missed/not understood

The Math 115 course is not designed to really teach students who have never learnt Calc II before, but rather those who have already taken Calc II, there is not enough focus or guidance given to students when learning the material, but rather just a lecture and problem sets where the student is expected to understand the material perfectly off the bat. I think this is problematic when thinking about learning a new skill, and if more explanation was offered, not even at the expense of time, then I feel that a lot more students would enjoy and do better in this course.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Unless this course is a major requirement/pre-requisite, there is really no reason to take it. It's incredibly difficult and profoundly stressful.
I would recommend this course but perhaps with a different instructor.
If it is not a requirement, I would not take this course. The tests are extremely difficult and there is no curve. However, if you are more interested in math, this course may not be so bad.

I would not recommend this course to another student because your success in the class is far too determined on who your professor is. If they are used to the ability to depend on a professor to adequately teach them difficult topics, they should not take this course.
I would not recommend this course to anyone who doesn't have to take it because it often felt like no matter how hard I tried, I could not succeed.
No!
Probably not, I felt that much of the topics were rushed and were not always taught super well.
No, because the teacher was not the best and the problem sets did no match of with the level of knowledge we were taught.
Yes but I would definitely warn that if you havent already taken BC calc it is not the easiest course.

It is a necessary course but I definitely would recommend any student to come in already having taken it either during the summer or in high school. I dont think the course is created to facilitate new student learning.
